events.description: Nickel futures rose to approximately $17,500 per tonne from a one-month low.
Indonesia announced a reduction in mining permits to 260 million wet tons for 2026.

facts.fact_text: Nickel futures rose to around $17,500 per tonne, rebounding from a one-month low of $17,000.

evidences.evidence_text: Nickel futures rose to around $17,500 per tonne, rebounding from a one-month low of $17,000 touched earlier in February

facts.fact_text: Indonesia will cut mining permits to 260 million wet tons in 2026 from 379 million tons last year.

evidences.evidence_text: Indonesia, the world’s largest nickel ore producer, which confirmed it will cut mining permits to 260 million wet tons in 2026, down from 379 million tons last year.

claims.claim_text: The reduction in permits signals tighter availability of nickel feedstock for stainless steel and battery production.

evidences.evidence_text: The reduction signals tighter availability of nickel feedstock for both stainless steel and battery production

claims.claim_text: Enforcement actions against illegal mining are adding to supply uncertainty.

evidences.evidence_text: enforcement actions against illegal mining adding to supply uncertainty.

claims.claim_text: Progress in US and Canadian nickel projects underscores structural shifts in the global supply chain.

evidences.evidence_text: underscore structural shifts in the global nickel supply chain beyond Southeast Asia.

evidence.evidence_text: The reduction signals tighter availability of nickel feedstock
The move was largely supported by ongoing supply concerns linked to Indonesia
enforcement actions against illegal mining adding to supply uncertainty.
